fields.headline: Corrections and clarifications
fields.bodyText: • Arrows on a map of Britain pointed out the parliamentary constituencies where various products are made. But Sheffield Brightside and Hillsborough was unfortunately placed in York; Carlisle, home of custard creams, was relocated north of the Scottish border; and South West Bedfordshire slipped southwards into the neighbourhood of Chesham and Amersham (Concrete canvas to custard creams: All made in Britain, 5 July, page 20). • In pieces about the conflict in Sudan, some references to the peoples of the Nuba mountains referred to them as "Nubians". This is normally the name of a different group of peoples – whose roots stem from a historical heartland that ranges from northern Sudan into Egypt – so for the avoidance of confusion "Nubians" should have been avoided by us in writing about the inhabitants of the Nuba mountains (Fear stalks the hills for victims of Sudan's forgotten war, 4 July, page 1; 'The south's leaders sold us off', 4 July, page 19). • An article on the natural resources available in the Arctic and the impact their possible exploitation could have on indigenous people incorrectly named Aqqaluk Lynge as the former president of the Inuit Circumpolar Council. He is in fact the current chair of the council (Riches, but at a price? North pole braced for 21st century gold rush, 5 July, page 12.)
